content: Hokkien word for white people ***Ang mo*** or ***ang moh*** ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 紅毛; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *âng-mô͘ / âng-mn̂g*; lit. 'red hair') is a descriptor used to refer to [white people](/wiki/White_people). It is used mainly in [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia) and [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), and sometimes in [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand) and [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan). It literally means "[red-haired](/wiki/Red-haired)" and originates from [Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien), a variety of [Southern Min](/wiki/Southern_Min). Other similar terms include ***ang mo kow*** (紅毛猴; 'red-haired monkey'), ***ang mo kui*** (紅毛鬼; 'red-haired devil'), ***ang mo lang*** (紅毛儂 / 紅毛人; 'red-haired people'). Although the term has historically had some derogatory connotations, it has entered common parlance as a neutral term in Singapore and Malaysia, where it refers to a white person or, when used as an adjective, Western culture in general. ## Etymology and history The earliest origin for the term *ang mo* could be traced to the contact between [Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien) (Southern Min) speakers in southern [Fujian](/wiki/Fujian) with the [Portuguese Empire](/wiki/Portuguese_Empire) and [Dutch East India Company](/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company) during the [Haijin](/wiki/Haijin) ("Sea Ban") period in the 16th and 17th centuries. One of the earliest known uses of the term in writing is found in the early 1600s [Selden Map](/wiki/Selden_Map), which labels the [Maluku Islands](/wiki/Maluku_Islands) of Indonesia with *ang mo*, likely referring to the Dutch presence there. In the late 1500s, Ming Ministry of Justice official Wang Linheng submitted a memorial reporting on the arrival of "red-haired devils" on China's southern coast, while in 1755 Zhejiang provincial authorities reported on the arrival of "red hair" seafarers under British merchant James Flint. During the 17th century, the Dutch East India Company failed in its attempt to force their way into Fujian to trade in the 1620s during the [Sino-Dutch conflicts](/wiki/Sino-Dutch_conflicts) and were called *ang mo* by the locals. The Dutch East India Company and then the [Spanish Empire](/wiki/Spanish_Empire) had colonized [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan), and the Spanish built [Fort Santo Domingo](/wiki/Fort_Santo_Domingo) in [Tamsui](/wiki/Tamsui), [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan). The Dutch later drove the Spanish out and seized the fort, which also became known as the "City of the Red-Haired" (Chinese: 紅毛城; pinyin: *hóng máo chéng*; Pe̍h-ōe-jī: *Âng-mn̂g-siâⁿ*) in [Taiwanese Hokkien](/wiki/Taiwanese_Hokkien). [Dutch people](/wiki/Dutch_people) were known in Taiwan as *ang mo lang* ("red-haired people") in Taiwanese Hokkien. This is most likely because red hair is a relatively common trait among the Dutch. This historical term *ang mo lang* continues to be used in the context of Taiwanese history to refer to Dutch people. The Chinese characters for *ang mo* are the same as those in the historical Japanese term *kōmō* (紅毛), which was used during the [Edo period](/wiki/Edo_period) (1603–1868) as an epithet for (Northwestern Europeans) white people. It primarily referred to Dutch traders who were the only Europeans allowed to trade with Japan during the [Sakoku](/wiki/Sakoku), its 200-year period of isolation. Portuguese and Spanish traders were in contrast referred to as *[nanban](/wiki/Nanban_trade)* (南蛮), which is in turn cognate to the Chinese *[nanman](/wiki/Nanman)* and means "southern barbarians". During the 19th century, [Walter Henry Medhurst](/wiki/Walter_Henry_Medhurst) made a reference in his academic work *A Dictionary of the Hok-Këèn Dialect of the Chinese Language* that *âng mô* ("red haired") generally applied to the [English people](/wiki/English_people). With the large migration of [the Hoklo](/wiki/Hoklo_people) to [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia), predominantly [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia) and [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), the term *ang moh* became more widespread and was used to refer to white people in general. ## Racial controversy The term *ang mo* is usually viewed as racist and derogatory by white people. Others, however, maintain it is acceptable, making it in some contexts a [reclaimed word](/wiki/Reclaimed_word). Despite this, it is a widely used term, at least among non-Westerners. It appears, for instance, in Singaporean newspapers such as *[The Straits Times](/wiki/The_Straits_Times)*, and in television programs and films. ## Derogatory context In [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) and [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia), the term *ang mo sai* ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 紅毛屎; lit. 'red-haired shit') is a derogatory term used within the Chinese community for mocking other Chinese who are not able to read Chinese. - [Ang Mo Kio](/wiki/Ang_Mo_Kio) - [Barang](/wiki/Barang_(Khmer_word)) - [Bule](/wiki/Bule_(term)) - [Farang](/wiki/Farang) - [Gweilo](/wiki/Gweilo) - [Mat Salleh](/wiki/Mat_Salleh) - [Totok](/wiki/Totok) - Definition from the *Coxford Singlish Dictionary* - Definition from the *Dictionary of Singlish and Singapore English*
